s.text: Britain won, on average, 17 gold medals per Olympics in the five official games held in its imperial heyday before World War I. That average has dropped to only five medals per Olympics in the 17 held since.
The pool of potential athletes has expanded in other ways, too.
Her 1900 counterpart would still have had three years to wait.
Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success.
Environmental differences between the two groups could account for differing levels of athletic success.
(In this context, "secular" does not refer to a trend's lack of spirituality but to its longevity: Secular trends are long-term modifications, not just brief fluctuations.)
Trainers measure the rate of buildup of lactic acid in your muscles, then claim that their programs will control it.

Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing.
Probably the most striking change, though, is how much more quickly children are maturing.
Which brings us to another question: Will there come a time when the human machine will hit some sort of natural limit and an Olympic Games pass without a single record tumbling?
Race horses seem already to have hit that outer limit.
That is a claim that is impossible to test, because you cannot control, in an experimental sense, environmental differences among the study groups.
There is a good chance that our 1990 12-year-old already had started to menstruate.
